G.L. c. 208, \u00a7\u00a7 28, 37.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over the parties and the subject matter of this action pursuant to G.L. c. 208, §§ 28, 37; G.L. c. 209C, § 20; and G.L. c. 215, § 6, as the prior custody and parenting-time orders were entered by this Court and both parties and the Children presently reside in Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over the parties and the subject matter of this action pursuant to G.L. c. 208, §§ 28, 37; G.L. c. 209C, § 20; and G.L. c. 215, § 6, as the prior custody and parenting-time orders were entered by this Court and both parties and the Children presently reside in Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over the parties and the subject matter of this action pursuant to G.L. c. 208, §§ 28, 37; G.L. c. 209C, § 20; and G.L. c. 215, § 6, as the prior custody and parenting-time orders were entered by this Court and both parties and the Children presently reside in Massachusetts.

Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366 (1981).proposition: Massachusetts courts apply a two-part test for modification of custody or parenting-time orders: (1) whether there has been a material and substantial change in circumstances since the prior order; and (2) whether modification is in the best interests of the child. See Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366 (1981); Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006); Custody of Vera, 473 Mass. 325 (2015).
Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366 (1981).support_reasoning: Schuler is an alimony and child support modification case, not a custody or parenting-time case. The opinion articulates a one-part standard for modification of alimony/support—"a material change of circumstances"—and then discusses factors bearing on ability to pay and needs; it does not frame or apply a two-part test involving both (1) material and substantial change, and (2) best interests of the child. Thus, citing Schuler as authority for a specific two-part test for custody/parenting-time modification misstates its holding and context.
Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366 (1981).relevant_excerpt: “To be successful in an action to modify a judgment for alimony or child support, the petitioner must demonstrate a material change of circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment. Robbins v. Robbins, 343 Mass. 247, 249 (1961). Hinds v. Hinds, 329 Mass. 190, 191-192 (1952). … In determining whether to modify a support or alimony order, a probate judge must weigh all relevant circumstances.”

Custody of Vera, 473 Mass. 325 (2015).proposition: Massachusetts courts apply a two-part test for modification of custody or parenting-time orders: (1) whether there has been a material and substantial change in circumstances since the prior order; and (2) whether modification is in the best interests of the child. See Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366 (1981); Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006); Custody of Vera, 473 Mass. 325 (2015).
Custody of Vera, 473 Mass. 325 (2015).support_reasoning: The provided text is not Custody of Vera, 473 Mass. 325 (2015), but a criminal case involving murder and evidentiary issues. It does not concern family law, custody, or modification standards, and nowhere discusses a two-part test for modifying custody or parenting-time orders. Accordingly, this opinion, as provided, does not support the stated custody-modification proposition.
Custody of Vera, 473 Mass. 325 (2015).relevant_excerpt: [No relevant excerpt on custody or modification standards appears in the provided opinion text; it concerns a murder conviction, evidentiary rulings, and related criminal procedure issues.]

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.proposition: A significant change in a parent’s work schedule and corresponding availability for parenting time can constitute a material change warranting modification, particularly when it affects the child’s stability, safety, and routine. See Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981) (recognizing changes in the practical circumstances of care as relevant to modification); Haas v. Puchalski, 9 Mass. App. Ct. 555 (1980).
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.support_reasoning: Rolde is a divorce and initial custody/visitation decision, not a post‑judgment modification case. The opinion does not discuss any change in a parent’s work schedule, material change of circumstances, or modification standards; it simply affirms the trial judge’s original allocation of custody and visitation based on best interests and parental conflict. Citing Rolde for the proposition that a significant change in work schedule can be a material change justifying modification misstates what the case decides.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.relevant_excerpt: “The husband argues that the judge erred in awarding sole custody to the wife… However, in deciding issues involving custody, the overriding concern of the court must be the promotion of the best interests of the children and their general welfare… The judge did not abuse his discretion. He correctly applied these principles in deciding this question, and his conclusions are amply supported by his subsidiary findings…”

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: The change in the Defendant’s employment and work hours constitutes a substantial and material change in circumstances affecting the practical ability of the Defendant to safely and appropriately exercise his currently ordered parenting time, and therefore directly affects the Children’s best interests. See G.L. c. 208, § 28; G.L. c. 209C, § 20; Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003); Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: Custody of Kali is not a modification case and does not discuss what constitutes a ‘substantial and material change in circumstances’ under G.L. c. 208, § 28 or G.L. c. 209C, § 20. The father argued that the substantial‑change standard should apply, but the SJC expressly declined to reach that issue and instead analyzed an initial custody determination under the best‑interests standard in § 10(a). The opinion does mention the father’s long work hours as one factor in an initial best‑interests analysis, but it does not hold that a change in employment or work hours is a substantial change warranting modification of parenting time. Accordingly, it does not provide authority for the specific proposition claimed.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “We also decline to consider the father’s claim that the probate judge should have applied the ‘substantial change in the circumstances’ standard applicable to modification actions brought under G. L. c. 209C, § 20, rather than the ‘best interests of the child’ standard applicable to custody determinations under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a). … General Laws c. 209C, § 20, gives the Probate Court jurisdiction to modify an existing judgment for support, custody, or visitation. Such a modification should be made only if ‘a substantial change in the circumstances of the parties or the child has occurred.’”

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).proposition: The change in the Defendant’s employment and work hours constitutes a substantial and material change in circumstances affecting the practical ability of the Defendant to safely and appropriately exercise his currently ordered parenting time, and therefore directly affects the Children’s best interests. See G.L. c. 208, § 28; G.L. c. 209C, § 20; Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003); Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).support_reasoning: The opinion in Custody of Vaughn addresses the impact of domestic violence on custody determinations and the need for explicit findings regarding such violence. It does not discuss employment changes, work hours, or how such changes can constitute a substantial and material change in circumstances affecting a parent’s ability to exercise parenting time. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the specific proposition that a change in the defendant’s employment and work schedule is a material change affecting parenting time and the children’s best interests.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).relevant_excerpt: “Domestic violence is an issue too fundamental and frequently recurring to be dealt with only by implication. The very frequency of domestic violence in disputes about child custody may have the effect of inuring courts to it and thus minimizing its significance. Requiring the courts to make explicit findings about the effect of the violence on the child and the appropriateness of the custody award in light of that effect will serve to keep these matters well in the foreground of the judges’ thinking.”

Williams v. Massa, 431 Mass. 619, 626\u2.proposition: The Defendant’s pattern of leaving the Children with a third party (his roommate) during his court-ordered parenting time, without the Plaintiff’s consent and without consistent proof that this arrangement is safe, suitable, and reliable, further demonstrates that the current schedule no longer serves the Children’s best interests. See Williams v. Massa, 431 Mass. 619, 626–27 (2000) (best interests standard focuses on whether arrangement serves child’s welfare, stability, and safety).
Williams v. Massa, 431 Mass. 619, 626\u2.support_reasoning: The cited pages of Williams v. Massa deal with property division and, briefly, the procedural vehicle for changing custody (requiring a complaint for modification under G.L. c. 208, § 28). The opinion does not discuss a parent’s practice of leaving children with third parties during parenting time, nor does it elaborate that the best-interests standard focuses on whether a particular parenting-time arrangement is safe, suitable, and reliable. While the court notes that custody determinations must be in the children’s best interests, it does not supply the specific best‑interests formulation asserted in the proposition.
Williams v. Massa, 431 Mass. 619, 626\u2.relevant_excerpt: “A change in a custody judgment, however, should be made pursuant to a complaint for modification under G. L. c. 208, § 28. If the judge felt that joint legal custody put the children at risk, or was not in their best interests, because of the wife’s worrisome parenting behavior, then the judge should have ordered sole legal custody to the father.”

Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981)
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: The above circumstances constitute a material and substantial change since the April 15, 2021 Order, warranting modification of the parenting plan. See, e.g., Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981) (substantial change in circumstances standard); Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006) (modification appropriate when circumstances change and child’s best interests require adjustment).
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: Bouchard does not discuss the standard for *modification* of an existing custody or parenting order, nor does it mention a requirement of a material or substantial change in circumstances. The case concerns the criteria for an initial custody award on divorce and emphasizes that custody decisions must be based on the child’s welfare/best interests. Citing Bouchard specifically for a “substantial change in circumstances” standard is therefore inaccurate; Mason v. Coleman, not Bouchard, supplies that modification principle.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “In a proceeding involving custody of a child, ‘as matter of law and as matter of humanity’ ‘[t]he governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child’ (emphasis supplied)… This court will not sustain a custody award unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed.”

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: Massachusetts courts apply a two-part test for modification of custody or parenting-time orders: (1) whether there has been a material and substantial change in circumstances since the prior order; and (2) whether modification is in the best interests of the child. See Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366 (1981); Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006); Custody of Vera, 473 Mass. 325 (2015).
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: Mason v. Coleman is a removal/relocation case under G.L. c. 208, § 30, involving parents with joint legal and physical custody. The opinion repeatedly frames the standard as whether removal is in the children’s best interests, not as a general two-part test for modification of custody or parenting-time requiring a threshold showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances. The only mention of “substantial change in circumstances” appears in a block quote of the ALI Principles, not as a Massachusetts standard for modification orders, so this case does not itself establish or apply the two-part modification test described in the proposition.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 30, provides that ‘[a] minor child of divorced parents … shall not … be removed out of this [C]ommonwealth … without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ ‘The words “upon cause shown” mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child.’ Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 711 (1985), citing Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 (1976). … [W]e review her determination of the best interests of the children only for an abuse of discretion.”

Haas v. Puchalski, 9 Mass. App. Ct. 555.raw_text: Haas v. Puchalski, 9 Mass. App. Ct. 555 (1980)
Haas v. Puchalski, 9 Mass. App. Ct. 555.proposition: A significant change in a parent’s work schedule and corresponding availability for parenting time can constitute a material change warranting modification, particularly when it affects the child’s stability, safety, and routine. See Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981) (recognizing changes in the practical circumstances of care as relevant to modification); Haas v. Puchalski, 9 Mass. App. Ct. 555 (1980).
Haas v. Puchalski, 9 Mass. App. Ct. 555.support_reasoning: The opinion does not discuss any change in either parent’s work schedule, availability for parenting time, or related effects on the child’s stability or routine. Instead, it focuses on whether the mother’s wrongful removal of the child from the Commonwealth and the father’s ability to provide a settled home justify a transfer of custody, concluding there was no relevant change in circumstances warranting modification. Thus, Haas is about lack of sufficient changed circumstances, not about work-schedule changes as a material change.
Haas v. Puchalski, 9 Mass. App. Ct. 555.relevant_excerpt: “To warrant a transfer of custody from one parent to another, following a determination of custody in a divorce proceeding, there must be a relevant change in circumstances. … Although it may in fact be true that Raymond also offers a happy environment for Joshua, the evidence demonstrates that it is not a ‘settled home,’ … as the child would be taken care of by many different relatives. This ‘militates against [Raymond’s] becoming the capable custodian of [Joshua] which [Michele] has already proven to be.’”

Custody of Zia, 455 Mass. 327 (2009).proposition: It is in the best interests of the Children, pursuant to G.L. c. 208, §§ 28, 31 and relevant case law, including Custody of Kali, Custody of Vaughn, Williams v. Massa, and Custody of Zia, 455 Mass. 327 (2009), that the Court modify the current parenting-time arrangements to conform to the Defendant’s actual availability and to safeguard the Children’s need for stability, safety, and appropriate supervision.
Custody of Zia, 455 Mass. 327 (2009).support_reasoning: This opinion is a criminal homicide appeal and does not concern domestic relations, child custody, or the ‘best interests of the child’ standard under G.L. c. 208, §§ 28, 31. The reference to “Custody of Zia, 455 Mass. 327 (2009)” appears to be a miscitation or misidentification of this murder case, which provides no authority on modifying parenting-time arrangements, parental availability, or children’s stability and safety. Therefore, this case does not support the family-law proposition for which it is cited.
Custody of Zia, 455 Mass. 327 (2009).relevant_excerpt: The defendant was convicted of the murders in the first degree of Jay Schlosser and Heather Buchanan... He appealed from his convictions and from the denial of his post-conviction motions for a new trial and for postconviction discovery. The defendant argues that the trial judge erred in the admission and exclusion of certain evidence; the prosecutor erred in failing to disclose material evidence and in exceeding the proper scope of closing argument; and the judge erred in denying the postconviction motions.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Under G.L. c. 208, § 28, and, where applicable, G.L. c. 209C, § 20, the Court may “modify or change its judgment at any time” regarding custody and parenting time if it finds that a “material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties or the child has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the child.”

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: A revised parenting schedule that limits the Defendant’s overnights to those nights when he is not working, and is reasonably rested and available, will provide the Children with a more predictable, safe, and stable routine, consistent with G.L. c. 208, § 31 (best interests of the child as paramount in custody determinations) and G.L. c. 208, § 28.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7\u00a7 28, 31.proposition: It is in the best interests of the Children, pursuant to G.L. c. 208, §§ 28, 31 and relevant case law, including Custody of Kali, Custody of Vaughn, Williams v. Massa, and Custody of Zia, 455 Mass. 327 (2009), that the Court modify the current parenting-time arrangements to conform to the Defendant’s actual availability and to safeguard the Children’s need for stability, safety, and appropriate supervision.
